text: Thanks everyone, especially <@URAV154AV> - I guess my worries were stemming from the fact that I already have been in cybersecurity for 5 years previous to my current role, which would bring me closer to 7-8 years within the industry by the time I wrapped up my next role. Just wanted to be sure I wasn't shutting doors for myself. And I'll definitely check out the CMS group! :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
Ah I see sorry I misunderstood, but my thoughts still stand. I don’t think you can be pigeonholed if you can speak to results.

Also, if you enjoy the work, that’s all that matters!

FWIW, I’ve been at martech companies for over 8 years now and people reach out to me about roles in all kinds of industries all the time. If anything, I think cybersecurity is a great space to be in because it’s recognized as innovative and leading edge, even within marketing, so companies from all industries will want to bring those qualities to their orgs.

text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: junior (1-3 years of experience)

":rotating_light:Freelance copywriter rates question!!! A recruiter for a freelance jr CW position reached out and asked for my rates. And I have no idea what to say back. There are tons of resources out about freelance rate negotiation, but few actually give out real numbers and don't take into account experience and project type. 

If I have a few years of writing under my belt and the position is a set number of hours per week (either 20 or 40), should I base rate on hours, day, or project? And what $ range would you suggest I say to the recruiter? I know it all depends on the projects, but any tips here that won't scare the recruiter are probably way better than anything I've found online so far haha. "

<@URAV154AV> thank you so much - you've made me feel a lot better, honestly. I'm going to try my best to keep a foot within SaaS through freelance or something, but it's good to know that there will always be an option to return to SaaS if I realize that cyber isn't the endgame for me :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: thank you so much - you've made me feel a lot better, honestly. I'm going to try my best to keep a foot within SaaS through freelance or something, but it's good to know that there will always be an option to return to SaaS if I realize that cyber isn't the endgame for me

text:
IMO: Use the hours to determine a weekly/monthly retainer

$25-35/hr feels about right for a junior position
So for the 20 hours/week gig, say:

$30 x 20 = $600/week
Be prepared to offer a bulk discount for guaranteed hours, around 10-15%. Perhaps adjust your base rate to absorb this if you'd rather not give up the $ but still want to offer the "deal"

Ensure that you have an overage rate/clause too, so you can get paid for scope creep or weeks where it's 30 hours vs 20. If they won't agree to that, then up your base price.

Since it's retainer based, bill full amount even if it's a 5 hour week. Gives you an incentive to figure out how to work faster to effectively boost your base rate :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
I agree with <@U01AHL8AGBB>’s hourly rate for a junior-level.

This is also an often cited resource to help determine freelance rates for a variety of different content roles. Most people think these rates best reflect a mid-level freelancer, but it’s a good starting point.

<https://www.the-efa.org/rates/>

attachments.title: Editorial Rates - Editorial Freelancers Association
attachments.text: EFA Members: For more information, see the Rates Survey Report and Rates Survey Information pages.
attachments.fallback: Editorial Freelancers Association: Editorial Rates - Editorial Freelancers Association

text: I would want to know if it's an in-house recruiter vs third-party recruiter also. If it's third, they will expect lower rates and I would just pass.

elements.text: I would want to know if it's an in-house recruiter vs third-party recruiter also. If it's third, they will expect lower rates and I would just pass.

text: Not specifically related to content marketing, but networking and working on teams in general: “Assume everyone you meet is _more introverted_ than you. Go find someone and make them feel comfortable.” — It’s served me incredibly well when speaking on webinars, leading cross-team meetings, and going to trade shows!

elements.text: Not specifically related to content marketing, but networking and working on teams in general: “Assume everyone you meet is
than you. Go find someone and make them feel comfortable.” — It’s served me incredibly well when speaking on webinars, leading cross-team meetings, and going to trade shows!

text: I'd also want to know about contract length. If you're working with them for 6+ months (or any interval), the rate could change.

elements.text: I'd also want to know about contract length. If you're working with them for 6+ months (or any interval), the rate could change.
